The S. S. Osmanieh will resume her express sailings on May 8.

PALESTINE - SYRIA MAIL SERVICE.–The fast steamers Prince Abbas and Assouan leave Alexandria alternately on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for Jaffa (for Jerusalem), Caiffa (for Nazareth), Beyrouth (for Damascus), Tripoli, Alexandretta, and Mersina, continuing in alternate weeks to Larnaca (Cyprus).

party with the choice which the Government have made of a successor to carry on thé work. Sir Eldon Gorst, who, until he was called t/r his important post in the Foreign Offimthree years ago, was one of Lord Cromer a most trusted lieutenants, and has been successively in charge of some of the most important branches of the Egyptian Administration, will g0 back to Egypt with the whole public opinion i,f this country behind him His appointment was made after full consultation with L,r>l Cromer, and the Government have mud*- it because they believe it is the one best .calculated to maintain and continue Lord Cromer s policy. The Opposition endorse that view. There is no hesitation, no change of polies ; and the inevitable change of persons is reduced to a minimum by the choice of a successor who will carry on the work of the past. * To write the history of,Lord Cromer's admin istration would be to survey the progress of a country, moral and material, in all the multifarious brandies in which the development of a country can be fostered. Even* then it would not be complete, for it would not contain all those imponderabilia of diplomacy which du not appear in annual reports, but which formed perhaps the larger part of Lord Crbiner's personal burden. Nothing, however, can im press his work more deeply on the mind than the broad contrast between Egypt A* it is i to-day and as it was when he took up his I present post in 1883. Less than a quarter of a century has seen the transformation of the country and the whole interni.tional situation that was focussed in it. In 1883 Sir velyn Baring, as he then was, had already had no small experience of Egypt as Cofnmissioner of the Public Debt and Controller-General, but Egypt as he found it, on hi» return from India, was in a state appalling in proportion to his knowledge. Bankruptcy was a faict, and behind it lay the menace of foreign intervention. Arabi's revolutionary career had brought utter disorganization into the public services. The Egyptian Army was a rabble, demoralized by its defeat at our.hands, and on 1 the 'point of being shattered again by the hordes of Mahdism. Hicks Pasha's ill-starred I expedition had actually started from Khar- ' toum two lays before Sir Evelyn Baring took * up his post, and there was nothing for tho 1 new Consul-General to do but to wait for the almost certain disaster. The long Khartoum " entanglement, ending in our failure to save Gordon, was to follow. It was only typical of the blunders of a Ministry at home which had no policy, and could give no effective guidance or support to its representative in Cairo. The European nations were watching our proceed- I ings with suspicion and hostility. The first. * decision Lord Cromer had to take was to aban- ! don the Sudan. Eight years before his resig- I nation he has able to witness its reconquest, by a new native army, which was one of the

div.head: Armenian Charity Society.
div.p: The Société de Bienfaisance Arménienne, of which Boghos Pasha Nuhar is president, has increased the first prize of its lottery from frs. 1,000 to trs 3,000, and there are to be four second prizes of frs. 200 in place of two of frs. 100 each. The concession for the lottery has been given to Ahmed Effendi Kabbara.

div.head: Rabies in Egypt.
div.p: The Government Anti-Rabic Institute, since it was opened on 1st May last has had 451 persons under treatment, of whom 63 were Europeans resident in Egypt, and 21 patients came from Syria or Palestine expressly to be treated. The remaining 367 were Egyptians. Ont of the total number treated for hydrophobia only four died.

div.head: Dinka Laws.
div.p: Captain O'Sullivan, of the Royal Marines, has compiled a compendium of Dinka laws. When the work is published it will be a most useful guide to young administrators in the Sudan, who have to deal with this interesting tribe. The ordinary codes are not applied to the administration of the Upper Nile Province as the disputes are settled by tribal custom. During the last three years upwards of 1,600 cases of complaints about property right, in cattle and marriage disputes which have been submitted by the Dinka tribesmen have been settled by Sudan Government officials.

div.head: Cruelty to Horses.
div.p: A correspondent writes :-" I see that the cruel practice of dividing horses tails is becom-! ing very "fashionable" here. In a country such! as this, where flies are much in evidence, this ought not to be. Perhaps the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals might take this matter into consideration." We heartily endorse our correspondent's objection to so cruel a practice, and trust with him that not only the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, but all who have the opportunity of pointing out the suffering which such a practice causes, will lo their utmost to relieve animals who are unable to make appeal for kind treatment at the hands of their masters. We would also lay especial stress on this question as the summer months are at hand and the discomfort of the horses will be greatly increased not only by the summer swarms of flies, but also by the extreme heat. Let nature have play wherever it is possible.

div.head:
THE FINANCIAL CRISIS.
REPRESENTATIVE MEETING
div.p: Yesterday evening an important meeting was held at Alexandria. Representatives of all the leading banks, private banks, the Stock and ShareRrokers' Association,and a number of local capitalists were present. Although no decision was arrived at the general tone of the meeting was very satisfactory and all appeared to realise that the existing crisis bad been much exaggerated and that all serious bankers and capitalists ought to join'in discouraging the wild specula|tion that has of late beën encouraged by some | brokers and second-rate banks who induce their clients to carry over their shares from one settlement to another at exorbitant rates of interest. All present expressed a wish that the banks would do everything that lies in their power for the purpose of facilitating their clients by extending their advances on good local securities. The outlook was not cousidered to be dangerous, but the general opinion of the meeting was that new company flotations should be strictly discouraged for the time being, as the enormous increase in the number of recent issues was recognised on all sides as being one of the main reasons for the present plight of the local bourses. Unfortunately there there is an impression prevalent among a certain class of brokers that the banks are the natural enemies of the broking interest, and as long as this idea Jis persisted in, it will be difficult for any strong guiding influence, representing the various interests, to intervene in such crises on behalf of the general welfare. The direct results of the present situation will be to give a great impetus to rigorous bourse regulations which should in great measure prevent a recurrence of such a state of affairs as has of late been prevailing
The following is a summary of some of the views expressed. As the Press was not invited to attend, the report cannot be considered complete.

Mr. Michel Salvago, who spoke very well, said that to definite measures could be imposed on the persons engaged in the "report" business, as no regulations existed. Consequently nobody would at the present time agree to submit to any constraint. It was certain that everybody recognised the gravity of the situation, and all persons interested in the question ought to be urged to facilitate matters as much as they could. If the bankers agreed to such a policy, he was certain that we should see a sensible alleviation. | He added that for his part during the past two days he had discussed the situation with the leading financiers and all expressed themsalves willing to come forward with help.

The great precautions to take were to hinder any more issues for at least some months to come until the existing new issues could be digested.' Mr. Richter, the manager of the Deutsche Orientbank, said that undoubtedly the existing crisis had been greatly exaggerated. There was no need to fear, as they were all trembling at phantoms largely of their own imagination,
There really was no grounds for the slightest • panic. The good shares had not fallen very

considerably and serious capitalists were not really alarmed at the outlook. The weakness was solely due to the crowds of little speculators, who had been leil on to carry over continually. He proposed that this was the moment to form regulations for the bourse and to name a committee, which should draw up some strict and bindling rules. į It was clear, however, that the sensible proposition of Mr. Richter was not greatly to the fancy of the brokers, as they do not regard with favour the idea of a joint committee of bankers and brokers in such a case.
Mr. Nalimann made the suggestion that the banks ought to make advances on shares at the prices at which they actually stood.

Mr Kingham, manager of the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, said that the fault lay entirely with the stockbrokers, and others, who by executing orilers for people who were not in a position to take up the shares, and then by carrying them forward, had brought on this state of affairs The banks had warned them of the danger that was likely to arise from such proceedings and now that they had got into difficulties
they could not demand the banks to help them. - The banks were willing to lend money on

good securities to solvent parties up to the extent of the resources available for this branch of their businesses. They would naturally do everything that lay in their power by other means to avert any unpleasant consequences arising out of the recent fall in values.

Baron Jacques de Menasce proposed that a species of syndicate should be formed, which should make a thorough estimate of the real value of each share. Then the banks should be asked to keep the shares at this price in order to advance money on them He referred to the crisis in 1881 in Paris when the bourse obliged every agent de change to keep the shares at the same price for three months and not to ask for further margins.
The general tone of the meeting seemed to consider that such a policy was impossible as no such engageinent could be entered with here. . Mr. Escoffier, the manager of the Crédit

Lyonnais, declared that the banks were in no sense, at fault, as they had repeately urged the brokers not to ogg on their clients to indulge in speculation. The banks cannot be expected to take up their positions All the shares now being carried forward should be continued to be carried forward at moderate rates so as to prevent these shares being thrown on the market. The "reporters" had mude large profits and much depended on them

div.head:
LORD CROMER'S RESIGNATION.
IMPRESSION IN PARLIAMENT.
div.p: The following is an account of the scene in the House of Commons on the occasion of the announcentent of Lord Cromer's resignation from last Friday's "Morning Post" :

It is not often that the House of Commons shows itself so deeply impressed as it was yesterday by an announcement made in a tone of profound regret by Sir Edward Grey. It was to the effect that Lord Cromer, who for nearly ' a generation has been our Pro-Consul in Egypt, has found it necessary, for reasons of health, to resign the position in which he has done ' such noble work both for Egypt itself and for the British Empire The House was mores crowded than it has been on any day since the. t Easter holidays, and a certain feeling of tension was observable. Members on both sides had come down prepared for a prolonged straggle on procedure. An all-night sitting, wis fully expected, and by no means friendly glances were being exchanged across the floor of the House. But all hostile feelings were put aside & directly the object of the Foreign Secretary's rising became known, and the two sides vied, with each other in their demonstrations of sylapathy with Lord Cromer on the cause of his resignation and sorrow at the loss of his services. Nothing could have been better than the tone of Sir Edward Grey's statement, nor could any tribute to a great public servant have been more eloquent than the manner of its reception. It was heard in an impressive silence, unbroken except by the deep-toned cheers that rose from every quarter of the House when allusion was made to the regret the news would arouse.

The Liberal organ, "The Tribune,says: The announcement of Lord Cromer's resignation came as a dramatic surprise. Except for the metbers of the Cabinet, who approved the appointment of his successor on Wednesday evening, it is doubtful whether anybody in the House had received a hint of the momentous news. The resignation came to hand a week ago. When Sir Edward Grey made his announcement the suspicion arose, as it always does, that something more than reasons of health was at the bottom of Lord Cromer's decision. There is good authority for stating that this belief is groundless. Lord Cromer has been advised that he must on no 'account risk another hot weather in Egypt.

div.head: TELEGRAMS OF REGRET.
div.p: The following telegram was sent to Lord Cromer by the Alexandria General Produce Association :--The Committee of the Alexan., dria General Produce Association, convened to an extraordinary meeting, deeply regrets the departure of your Lordship and offers you an unanimous expression of homage for your most eminent contribution to the well-being and prosperity of the country.

The following is Lord Cromer's reply to Mr. C. de Tschudi, president of the Associaton :-- I beg you to accept and to communicate to the Committee of the Association over which you preside my sincerest thanks for the telegram which I have just received from you, the cordial terms of which have given me great pleasure.

The following telegram has been sent to Lord Cromer by Mr. Emmanuel Benachi, presis dent of the Greek community. The Greek community of Alexandria, convened to an extraordinary meeting, charges me to express to your Lordship the regret caused by your departure from Egypt, a regret which is all the deeper because it is to reasons of health that it is due. Our community 'desires to render Thomage to the results of your work in Egypt which has left an ineffaceable memory and of which our colony gratefully welcomes the benefits."

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive gave a farewell luncheon to' Lord and Lady Cromer yesterday at Ab- ; deen Palace to which he invited the Ministers and Advisers, and several ladies. I
The Khedive's farewell reception at Cairo will be held, as we have already announced, on the 25th inst., the first audience being granted to the Ulemas at 8 30 a.m.

The Khedivah will receive the Princesses of the Khedivial family and native ladies at Koubbeh Palace from 9 to ME 30 a.m ; Euro pean ladies from 4 to 5 p.nly and at 5 p.m. the wives of the Diplomatic Agents.

div.head: CAIRO CAB STRIKE.
div.p: Yesterday morning a deputation of Cairo cab-drivers visited the gouvernorat to demand from the Governor a higher tarif than the present one. The Governor promised to take the matter into consideration. The drivers, however, have proved unwilling to await. developments and people in Cairo are in the unenviable position of being unable to hire an arabeah, all the drivers having gone on strike. Not a single cab is to be found in the streets, and the only public conveyances running are the trams, buses, and the three or four motor cabs of which the capital boasts, and these, of course, are altogether inadequate to satisfy the demands of the public. Business is seriously hampered and the situation is viewed with considerable alarm..

div.head: CONTRACTS IN MOROCCO.
div.p: THE CONCESSIONS TO GERMANY-
ENFORCED RENOUNCEMENT
PROBABLE.
( Gazette's Special Serviee.)
LONDON, Thursday.

The action of the Commissioner of the Sultan of Morocco in giving the contracts for various public works to German firms secretly, and coming after so frequent complaints have been made about Germany's agressive commercial activity in Morocco, has created a very uneasy feeling. France feels that the sacrifices which she made at Algeciras have been futileand that the Morocco question with all its dangers may at any time be revived The. "Times" says that several European legations intend to pro-test on behalf of their governments and to dispute the legality of the contracts. It is generally believed that in the end Germany will be compelled to renounce the contracts and that the works will be put under adjndication as was formerly agreed.

div.head: SABA PASHA'S RESIGNATION. MAZLOUM PASHA'S LETTER.
div.p: In a letter informing the Postmaster-General of the acceptance of his resignation Ahmed Mazloum Pasha, Minister of Finance, writes :I hasten to inform you that, while sincerely regretting this determination, I can only, in consequence of the reasons which have inspired iti accept it, and I grant you, therefore, an orylinary leave of absence of three months and a half from the 1st of June next, at the expiration of which you will be entitled to your lo claims to pension. If it is difficult to you to sever your conrection with an administration to to which you have been attached for thirty five years and which you have directed for 9 twenty years, my department on its side ex periences the most earnest regret at losing the o service of so eminent an official after a suffi- 1 ciently lengthy career wholly devoted to the s development of the Postal Administration, which, under your able and intelligent direc-d tion has advanced so remarkably and made such important progress. In conclusion, In would express my heartiest thanks and those of the Government for your good and valuable i services and offer you our sincere congratulations upon the degree of prosperity to which you have guided the Postal Administration.

div.head: DELTA LAND AND INVESTMENT COMPANY LIMITED.
div.p: A telegram was received by the Cairo office of this company from London advising that the general meeting held there on Tuesday went off in a satisfactory manner : in other words, the resolutions submitted to the meeting were approved and passed by the shareholders, and therefore, in future, the administration of the company will be entirely in Egypt. The company has also, we are informed, completed the following important
transactions - - They have purchased from Messrs Suares

Freres & Co, 146 feddans of land adjoining their Meadi Estate with a river frontage of about 1500 metres. They have also purchased from Messrs Karkour Brothers a plot of about 36'feddans that intervened between the company's Meadi estate and the Suares land, The purchase price of these two properties amounts to about L.E. 350,000.

The company has sold to Messrs De Vries and Boutigny their "Moulin Français" properties, situated in Cairo and Alexandria for a sum of about L.E. 246,600. It will be remembered that the Delta Land Company purchased these properties about 12 months ago from the Société Anonyme des Moulins d'Egypte for a sum of L.E. 160,000. Further the company have made an issue of 100,000 new shares to Messrs Suares Freres and Co., at the price of L.E. 3.15. O per vhare nett, and Messrs Suares
Fretes and Co, have entered into engageiments whereby these shares are to be held by "them for a considerable period.
Mr. Robert Rollo of the firm of Messrs Suqres Freres and Co., has joined the board of the Delta Land Company.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ESTATEE, LIMITED.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTR."

Sir,--As many enquiries are being made by our shareholders as to the annual dividend (in addition to the 5% interim dividend already paid) on the shares of the above company, and rumours have been promoted to the effect that our annual dividend would be passed, I shall be glad if you will kindly inform the shareholders, through your columns, that such ru. mours have no foundation in fact, and there is no question whatever that the dividend will be paid. Owing to the enormous increase in the
company's business, the books this year will - take rather longer to audit than last year, but
the directors-report and balance sheet will be placed in the hands of the shareholders at
the earliest possible date. - I am, Yours faithfully.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lord Cromer's youngest son, the Hon. Evelyn Baring, left Port Said on Sunday by the Bibby line Cheshire in charge of his governess.
The Sirdar will leave Khartoum shortly for Cairo to confer with Sir Eldon Goret.
Lady Wingate has arrived at Stafford House, Dunbar, from Egypt, for several month's residence.
Three months' leave of absence has been granted to Mr, A. T. Lloyd, Ministry of the Interior, dating from the 12th inst., and to Bimbashi Vernon Jervis, Cairo City Police, dating from the 1st June.
Captain Blake, Commanding the Cairo City Fire Brigade, has been granted three and a half months' leàve of absence, dating from the 5th of June. •

Mr. SiJney Davis, of the firm of Messrs. S. Davis and Sons, tlie well-known wholesale furniture manufacturers of London, will arrive at Alexandria by the 8.S. Schleswig on tho 22nd inst. The firm is well-known in Egyptian commercial circles tor their enterprise and reliability. While in Alexandria Air. Davis will stay at the New Khédivial Hotel.

div.head:
PRESENTATION OF COLOURS TO 1ST. BATTALION ROYAL DÜBLIN FUSILIERS.
OFFICIAL ACCOUNT.
div.p: At 10.30 a.m , on Friday, 5th April 1907, the 1st Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers (consisting of eight guards of 35 files each, with Band and Drums), w^s formed up in line on the Polo Ground, Sports Club, Alexandria, facing South, for inspection by Field Marshal H.R.H. the Duke of Connaught, who arrived on the ground at 11 a.m., and was received with a Royal Salute.

HUH. accompanied by General Bullock and their Staffs, inspected the line, artd then proceeded to the SalutiDg Point. The Parade was now formed' for the Trooping of the Gld Colours, which ceremony having been carried out, the escort for the Colours, commanded by Major Downing, with Lieutenants Franklknif and Brodhurst-Hill canying the Colours, marched for the last time down the front of the Battalion, the Band playing "Auld Lang Syne," and returned by the rear of the line where the Old Colours were left, cased, in charge of two Colour Sergeants.
Three sides of a square were then formed, the Drums being piled in the centre, the New Colours were uncased and placed in position on the Drums.

The Rev. F. B. N. Norman Lee, Chaplain to the Forces, proceeded with the Consecration *>^ Service, opening with the Hymn "Brightly gleams our Banner" ; on the conclusion of the Service, the King's Colour was handed by Major Bromilow to H. R. H, who presented it to'Lieut Frankland; similarly, the Regimental Colour was banded to H. R. H. by Major ^ ,
Rutherford and presented to Lieut Brodhurst- Hill. Both Officers received the Colours from H.R.H. on bended knee.
Field Marshal H.RJFL then addressed the Battalion as . tpjlowB
Colonel Cliapmau, Offioers, Non-Commissioned Officers and Men of tlie 1st Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers :
As your Colonel-in-Chief it gives me the greatest pleasure to present you thu day with yorr new Colours to replace-those you received in 1866.

In confiding to you these emblems of Our Sovereign and Our Country I feel I am entrusting them to those who will know how to honour and respoot them in the same way that they have cherished those Colours from which we have just taken leave.
Fusiliers, you belong to an old and distinguished Regiment who have nobly borne their ' share in their Country's battles and in the bnilding up of our great Empire.

Formed originally from companies thatsinoe 1746 had taken their part in the conquests in India under the East Indian Company, in to the Madras European Regiment in 1887, you took part in all the battles in that country up to 1870. You fought with distinction at Seriugapatam, Arcot, the Indian Mutiny and the Relief of Lucknow, and served under such distinguished men as Havelock, Outran, Cliva, Grant and Neill who fell at the head,'of the Regiment at the Relief of Lucknow. It was at that time you received the soubriquet of "Une caps" which is commemorated to this day by the unique colour ot your forage caps.

In 1843 the Regiment became the 1st Madras Fusiliers, and in 1862 the 102nd Regiment of Foot (Royal Madras Fusiliers), in 1873 you were linked with the Bombay Fusiliers - and in 1884 the Regiment received its present title ot the Royal Dublin Fusiliers.

Since then the Regiment has seen a great deal of foreign service and fought with the greatest distinction in the South African War and distinguished itself with the Irish Brigade under General Hart in the Relief of Ladysmith, the Tugela Heights and Laings Nek

Irishmen have at all times shown & dashand bravery that have made them famous in the annals of the British Army This Regiment has at all times shown such a splendid spirit. in many a. hard fought battle, often against the greatest odds, that I feel confident that should you again be called on to fight the enemies of your Country you will respond with the same loyalty and devotion to duty that have at all times been shown by those that have gone before you. Representing as you do the capital of Old Ireland I know that you will never fail in the moment of need and will know how to maintain the noble. traditions of your Regiment and that your King and Country will ever have reason to be proud of your services.
Colonel Chapman, Commanding the Battalion, them made the following reply -

"Your Royal Highness, on behalf of the Officers, Non-Commissioned Officers and men of the Battalion, I offer you our sincerest thanks for the great honour you have done us to-day, an honour doubly appreciated by us, in that we have received these Colours from our Colonelin-Chief Yonr gracious and inspiring words will ever be an incentive to us, to uphold the traditions of the past, and to add fresh lustre to them in the future, and I wonld ask you, Sir, to convey our Homage to His Majesty The King, and to assore him that the - Royal
Dublin Fusiliers will ever be found ready to | uphold his authority, and defend his Empire."

The Battalionreformed line, and received their New Colours with "presented arms," which were marched in "slow time" to their position in the centre of the line, the band I playing "God Save The King."

The Battalion now marched past, and reforming into line, advanced in Röview Order; balting opposite HER H., the New Colour being now lowered for the first time to their Colonelin-Clief in a Royal Salute.
Thus ended a most impressivo ceremony, which will long remain in the memories of | those who were fortunate enough to be spec tators.
The Old Colours were presented to F.M., H.R.H. the Colonel-in-Chief, who graciously accepted them, and intimated that he would have them hung in Clarence Honse.
